Yelp.title: Samantha at Ergeon provide a very responsive and professional customer experience. She expertly captured my project needs and provided a detailed proposal in three business days. I wish all service providers were this good!

Google.title: From the very start, Kelly was in constant contact. She has been truly helpful with all her suggestions and has been a true professional all throughout. She was quick to address any concerns we had and always made herself available at a moments notice. The estimate was done virtually and quotes were provided almost immediately. Kelly has made the planning process that much easier for us.

regulations.title: Permits & Regulations
regulations.description: See the undefined Permits & Regulations for undefined

faq.front-yard: 3 feet within 15 feet of the back of sidewalk, or the back of curb, if there is no sidewalk.  6 feet within front setback
faq.side-yard: 3 feet within 10 feet setback, 6 feet beyond setback on street side yard, 6 feet + 2 feet lattice 50% open on interior side yard
faq.setback: 15 feet for front yard, 10 feet for street side for 6 feet height fences (except where a minimum 10 feet landscape parkway is provided within the right-of-way)
faq.corner-lot-rules: 3 feet Max height on 50 feet triangle visibility area measured from property lines or edge of right of way.

articles.description: If you’re looking to get a new fence in California, it’s important to know about the laws surrounding fences and home improvement projects. Our post will go over some important things to keep in mind.

When it’s time to get a new fence it’s important to always use a reputable, licensed, and insured contractor. Some people try to cut costs by using unlicensed contractors, but this can end up being a major issue if any problems happen during the installation or down the line. In this post, we’ll go over the main reasons why you should always use a licensed and insured fence contractor.
